column4: you wouldn't probably say that if you had a console-only machine
why bother with X, there are like 400 console-based and ncurses apps that do that
well the console has its charms but some stuff are made to be graphical. cd burners and rippers are but one example where i preffer the gui over command line...
not the command line!  ncurses makes quite a capable frontend
ncurses are fine for some stuff. but not all. i use ncurses for bt and most config stuff, but my fav burner is still graveman
lol, THAT you are perfectly right about!
my secondary machine (currently running gentoo) is a 166mhz P1 with 75MB of RAM... X will never run on that machine
its saving grace is that it has no ATA devices but the CD-RW/DVD-ROM combo drive... I plan to make it a videolan server and networked CD burning machine
X runs fine here on slow hardware, but gnome and kde is banned! i used to run DSL on a 64mb, 500mhz spare pc :)
right now I'm second-guessing my decision to go gentoo on it though... ncurses takes FOREVER to emerge
best distro for low performance pc i've ever tried is slackware
You wouldn't say that if you'd ever tried to install it onto a software raid, and with some other filesystem than ext2/3 or reiser
can't you install ncurses binaries instead in gentoo?
ah, never tried software raid with slack
sadly, gentoo is built as a source-based distro... it's somewhat crippled in that respect
freebsd gives you option to either compile or install binaries. somehow i thought gentoo had that option as well. damn
and there are a couple 2.6 features that I find I cannot live without...  ATAPI burning... XFS/JFS support...
2.6 work well on hardware that old otherwise?
